Award.AwardTitle: Impacts and Consequences of Predicted Climate Change on Andean Glaciation and Runoff
Award.AbstractNarration: 0519415<br/>Vuille<br/>The tropical Andes are one of the regions of the globe where recent climate change is<br/>most evident, consistent with the notion that high-elevation mountain ranges that extend into the<br/>mid-troposphere will experience greater warming. As a result glaciers are receding throughout the<br/>tropical Andes, with potentially severe consequences for the availability of drinking water, and<br/>water for irrigation, mining and hydropower production.<br/>General Circulation Models (GCMs) run with a 2.CO2 scenario predict an additional<br/>warming of more than 2.5.C by the end of the century. However large uncertainties exist about<br/>these future projections, especially because the coarse resolution of GCMs is inadequate to<br/>resolve the meso- and local-scale circulation features associated with the steep Andean<br/>topography. To accurately understand and predict future climate change and its impact on tropical<br/>Andean glaciers, higher resolution models and a better simulation of variables other than<br/>temperature are required.<br/>We propose to simulate climate variability and change in the Andes under both presentday<br/>conditions (1961-90 and 1958-2001) and two different IPCC-SRES emission scenarios<br/>(2071-2100) with a regional climate model (PRECIS) to gain a better understanding of how<br/>future climate change might affect tropical Andean glaciers.<br/>Results from our regional climate model will be validated with observational data from<br/>space before they are used as input into a glacier-climate model (ITGG 2.0) to simulate how<br/>glacier mass balance will be affected by future climate change. The simulated present-day mass<br/>balance of selected glaciers will be compared with observational records from the tropical Andes<br/>to verify the accuracy of our results. To gain a better understanding of the consequences of<br/>glacier retreat, the ITGG 2.0 model will also be used to simulate changes in runoff from Andean<br/>watersheds. The anticipated results of our proposed research are:<br/>1) The use of a high-resolution model will improve simulations of climate in this area of complex<br/>terrain and yield more accurate predictions of future climate change than are available to date<br/>from GCM.s.<br/>2) An in-depth model validation with observational data will lead to a better assessment of model<br/>performance (for both the RCM and the ITGG 2.0).<br/>3) We will for the first time establish robust projections of how glaciation and runoff will change<br/>in this region at the end of the 21st century. This has important implications for the anticipated<br/>future water shortage in the region and will provide much needed information to implement<br/>adaptation and mitigation strategies.<br/>4) Finally we anticipate a significant model improvement as a result of using regional climate<br/>model data instead of course resolution reanalysis data as input into the ITGG 2.0 model.<br/>We strongly believe that our proposed research addresses a key issue related to future<br/>climate change in the tropical Andes, which is of high scientific interest but also of primary<br/>socio-economic relevance for the region. The potential for a future water crisis is evident and this<br/>water shortage is related to a projected future change in runoff, due to the observed rapid glacier<br/>retreat. The scientific merit of this proposal is therefore to gain a better understanding of both<br/>mechanisms and consequences related to the disappearance of tropical Andean glaciers. This<br/>increased knowledge on how fast and how far glaciers will recede and how much this will affect<br/>future runoff and water availability from the Andes will have a significant and broad impact on<br/>local economies and populations. Without a better and much more detailed knowledge of how<br/>future climate change will affect glaciological and hydrological systems in the Andes, no<br/>mitigation and adaptation strategies can be put in place.<br/><br/>
